id: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.
name: Series name used for displaying in tooltip and filtering with legend, or updating data and configuration with setOption.
zlevel:
zlevel value of all graphical elements in .

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.
z:
z value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller z values may be overwritten by those with larger z values.

z has a lower priority to zlevel, and will not create new Canvas.
center:
Center position of Sunburst chart, the first of which is the horizontal position, and the second is the vertical position.

Percentage is supported. When set in percentage, the item is relative to the container width, and the second item to the height.

Example: 

// Set to absolute pixel values
center: [400, 300]
// Set to relative percent
center: ['50%', '50%']
radius:
Radius of Sunburst chart. Value can be:

  • number: Specify outside radius directly.

  • string: For example, '20%', means that the outside radius is 20% of the viewport size (the little one between width and height of the chart container).

  • Array.<number|string>: The first item specifies the inside radius, and the second item specifies the outside radius. Each item follows the definitions above.
data:
The data structure of series-sunburst.data is like tree. For example:

[{
    name: 'parent1',
    value: 10,          // value of parent node can be left unset, and sum of
                        // children values will be used in this case.
                        // If is set, and is larger than sum of children nodes,
                        // the reset can be used for other parts in parent.
    children: [{
        value: 5,
        name: 'child1',
        children: [{
            value: 2,
            name: 'grandchild1',
            itemStyle: {
                // every data can have its own itemStyle,
                // which will overwrites series.itemStyle and level.itemStyle
            },
            label: {
                // label style, the same to above
            }
        }]
    }, {
        value: 3,
        name: 'child2'
    }],
    itemStyle: {
        // itemStyle of parent1, which will not be inherited for children
    },
    label: {
        // label of parent1, which will not be inherited for children
    }
}, {
    name: 'parent2',
    value: 4
}]
data.value: Value for each item. If contains children, value can be left unset, and sum of children values will be used in this case.
data.name: Name displayed in each sector.
data.link:
Link address that redirects to when this sector is clicked. Only useful when series-sunburst.nodeClick is set to be 'link'.

See series-sunburst.data.target.
data.target: Like target attribute of HTML <a>, which can either be 'blank' or 'self'. See series-sunburst.data.link.
data.label:
label sets the text style for every sectors.

Priority: series.data.label > series.levels.label > series.label.

Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.
data.label.rotate:
If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

By default, it is 'radial'. If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

The following example shows different rotate settings:
data.label.align: Align of text, which can be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. Note that 'left' stands for inner side, and 'right' stands for outer side.
data.label.minAngle: If angle of data piece is smaller than this value (in degrees), then text is not displayed. This is used for hiding text for small piece of data.
data.label.position:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.
data.label.distance:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.
data.label.offset: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.
data.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]
data.label.color:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
data.label.verticalAlign:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}
data.label.lineHeight:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}
data.label.backgroundColor:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
data.label.borderColor:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
data.label.padding:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.
data.label.shadowOffsetX: Shadow X offset of the text block.
data.label.shadowOffsetY: Shadow Y offset of the text block.
data.label.width:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.
data.label.height:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.
data.label.textBorderColor:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
data.label.textShadowOffsetX: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
data.label.textShadowOffsetY: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.
data.label.rich:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

data.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
data.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
data.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
data.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
data.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
data.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
data.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
data.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
data.emphasis: Item style when mouse is hovering. See highlightPolicy.

data.emphasis.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
data.emphasis.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

data.highlight.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

data.downplay.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
data.downplay.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
data.downplay.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
data.downplay.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
data.downplay.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
data.downplay.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
data.downplay.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
data.downplay.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
data.downplay.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
data.downplay.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
data.children: Children nodes, which is recursively defined. In the same format to series-sunburst.data.
label:
label sets the text style for every sectors.

Priority: series.data.label > series.levels.label > series.label.

Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.
label.rotate:
If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

By default, it is 'radial'. If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

The following example shows different rotate settings:
label.align: Align of text, which can be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. Note that 'left' stands for inner side, and 'right' stands for outer side.
label.minAngle: If angle of data piece is smaller than this value (in degrees), then text is not displayed. This is used for hiding text for small piece of data.
label.position:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.
label.distance:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.
label.offset: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.
label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

highlightPolicy:
When mouse hovers a sector, the sector is emphasized. If highlightPolicy is set to be 'descendant', then the sector and its descendant will be highlighted, and others will be downplayed. If highlightPolicy is 'ancestor', then the sector and its ancestors will be highlighted. If it is set to be 'self', then the sector will be highlighted and others downplayed. If it is set to be 'none', then others will not be downplayed.

The highlightPolicy value above is the default value 'descendant'. We use dispatchAction to highlight certain sector. Target sector will use the style of emphasis, and related sectors decided by highlightPolicy uses the style of highlight, and others use downplay.

itemStyle: {
    color: 'yellow',
    borderWidth: 2,
    emphasis: {
        color: 'red'
    },
    highlight: {
        color: 'orange'
    },
    downplay: {
        color: '#ccc'
    }
}

If highlightPolicy is set to be 'ancestor', then the result looks like:
nodeClick:
The action of clicking a sector, which can be:

  • false: nothing happens.
  • 'rootToNode': use the clicked sector as root.
  • 'link'Ôºöif link is set, the page will redirect to it.
sort:
Sorting method that sectors use based on value, which is the sum of children when not set. The default value 'desc' states for descending order, while it can also be set to be 'asc' for ascending order, or null for not sorting, or callback function like:

function(nodeA, nodeB) {
    return nodeA.getValue() - nodeB.getValue();
}
renderLabelForZeroData: If there is no name, whether need to render it.
emphasis: Item style when mouse is hovering. See highlightPolicy.
emphasis.label:
label sets the text style for every sectors.

Priority: series.data.label > series.levels.label > series.label.

Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.
emphasis.label.rotate:
If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

By default, it is 'radial'. If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

The following example shows different rotate settings:
emphasis.label.align: Align of text, which can be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. Note that 'left' stands for inner side, and 'right' stands for outer side.
emphasis.label.minAngle: If angle of data piece is smaller than this value (in degrees), then text is not displayed. This is used for hiding text for small piece of data.
emphasis.label.position:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.
emphasis.label.distance:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.
emphasis.label.offset: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.
emphasis.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

emphasis.label.verticalAlign:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}
emphasis.label.lineHeight:

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{

        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}
emphasis.label.backgroundColor:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
emphasis.label.borderColor:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
emphasis.label.padding:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.
emphasis.label.shadowOffsetX: Shadow X offset of the text block.
emphasis.label.shadowOffsetY: Shadow Y offset of the text block.
emphasis.label.width:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.
emphasis.label.height:

emphasis.label.rich:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

emphasis.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
emphasis.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
emphasis.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
emphasis.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
highlight.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

downplay.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

levels:
Multiple levels

Sunburst chart has a leveled structure. To make it convenient, we provide a levels option, which is an array. The first element of it is for returning to parent node when data mining. The following elements are for levels from center to outside.

For example, if we don't want the data mining, and want to set the most inside sector to be red, and text to be blue, we can set the option like:

series: {
    // ...
    levels: [
        {
            // Blank setting for data mining
        },
        {
            // The most inside level
            itemStyle: {
                color: 'red'
            },
            label: {
                color: 'blue'
            }
        },
        {
            // The second level
        }
    ]
}

    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'

levels.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
levels.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
levels.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
levels.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
levels.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
levels.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
levels.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
levels.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
levels.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
levels.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
levels.emphasis: Item style when mouse is hovering. See highlightPolicy.
levels.emphasis.label:
label sets the text style for every sectors.

Priority: series.data.label > series.levels.label > series.label.

Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.
levels.emphasis.label.rotate:
If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

By default, it is 'radial'. If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

The following example shows different rotate settings:
levels.emphasis.label.align: Align of text, which can be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. Note that 'left' stands for inner side, and 'right' stands for outer side.
levels.emphasis.label.minAngle: If angle of data piece is smaller than this value (in degrees), then text is not displayed. This is used for hiding text for small piece of data.
levels.emphasis.label.position:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.
levels.emphasis.label.distance:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'„ÄÅ'insideRight').

See: label position.
levels.emphasis.label.offset: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.
levels.emphasis.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

levels.highlight.label.formatter:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,

}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
levels.highlight.label.verticalAlign:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}
levels.highlight.label.lineHeight:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}
levels.highlight.label.backgroundColor:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
levels.highlight.label.borderColor:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
levels.highlight.label.padding:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.
levels.highlight.label.shadowOffsetX: Shadow X offset of the text block.
levels.highlight.label.shadowOffsetY: Shadow Y offset of the text block.
levels.highlight.label.width:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.
levels.highlight.label.height:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
levels.highlight.label.textShadowOffsetX: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
levels.highlight.label.textShadowOffsetY: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.
levels.highlight.label.rich:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

levels.highlight.itemStyle:
Style of Sunburst sectors.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
levels.highlight.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
levels.highlight.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
levels.highlight.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
levels.downplay: Item style when mouse is hovering unrelated items. See highlightPolicy.
levels.downplay.label:
label sets the text style for every sectors.

Priority: series.data.label > series.levels.label > series.label.

Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.
levels.downplay.label.rotate:
If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

By default, it is 'radial'. If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

The following example shows different rotate settings:
levels.downplay.label.align: Align of text, which can be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. Note that 'left' stands for inner side, and 'right' stands for outer side.
levels.downplay.label.minAngle: If angle of data piece is smaller than this value (in degrees), then text is not displayed. This is used for hiding text for small piece of data.
levels.downplay.label.position:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

Style can be set in series.itemStyle for sectors of this series, or series.levels.itemStyle for the whole level, orseries.data.itemStyle for single sector. If series.data.itemStyle is defined, it will cover the setting of series.itemStyle and series.levels.itemStyle.

Priority: series.data.itemStyle > series.levels.itemStyle > series.itemStyle.

In ECharts, emphasis is for styles when mouse hovers. For Sunburst charts, there are two extra states: highlight for highlighting items that relates to the emphasized one, and downplay for others when emphasizing an item. See highlightPolicy.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.color:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}
levels.downplay.itemStyle.borderColor: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.borderWidth: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.borderType: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.shadowBlur:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}
levels.downplay.itemStyle.shadowColor: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.
levels.downplay.itemStyle.opacity: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
animationThreshold: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.
animationDuration:
Duration of the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDuration: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}
animationEasing: Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at easing effect example.
animationDelay:
Delay before updating the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect.

For example:

animationDelay: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.
animationDurationUpdate:
Time for animation to complete, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDurationUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}
animationDelayUpdate:
Delay before updating animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effects.

For example:

animationDelayUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.
